Award.AwardTitle: US-Egypt Cooperative Research: Origin and Economic Potential of Some Banded Iron Ore Deposits from the Central Eastern Desert of Egypt
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports collaborative research between Dr. A. El-Shazly, Department of Geology, Marshall University, West Virginia and Dr. Khalil Ebeid, Geology Department of Alexandria University. They plan to study the banded iron ore deposits occurring in the Eastern Desert of Egypt to identify the processes involved in the genesis of these banded iron ores and to determine the age of formation.

Intellectual Merit
By focusing primarily on the deposits of Umm Nar and Wadi Kareim, which are characterized by exceptionally high Fe/Si ratios, US and Egyptian PIs will attempt to identify the processes involved in the genesis of these banded iron ores and the geological timeline of each. Field work will be carried out to map the ore bodies and establish their relations to specific structures. Petrological and whole rock geochemical analysis for major and trace elements will help classify the deposits, constrain the conditions of their metamorphism, and identify the tectonic setting of their formation. Microthermometric and laser micro-Raman studies of fluid inclusions will lead to the identification of the roles of diagenesis, hydrothermal activity, and metamorphism in the formation of these deposits through characterization of the fluid compositions and their conditions of entrapment. U-Pb dating of individual zircon crystals separated from the iron ores and their intercalated rocks using laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry at the University of Arizona will constrain the timing of hydrothermal alteration and metamorphism through dating specific chemical zones within each crystal.

Broader Impacts
The broader impacts of this project will promote the development of junior scientists. The involvement of an M.S. level student from Egypt and a US undergraduate from Marshall University will lead to a better understanding of educational systems and cultures for both groups. Participation of a Marshall University undergraduate in field work in Egypt and subsequent training in techniques of geochemical analysis and scientific research will be beneficial to the student. The proposed geochemical studies will result in a better evaluation of the economic potential of these iron ores, as it will determine the concentrations of any elements deemed undesirable for the steel industry as well as the overall grade of the ores.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Banded Iron Formations (BIFs) are the primary source of iron ore, believed to have formed by sedimentation of iron oxides on the ocean floor. The formation of sizeable banded iron formations requires buildup of dissolved iron in ocean water followed by its precipitation. Because the soluble form of iron is ferrous (Fe2+) rather than ferric (Fe3+) which precipitates readily, the formation of banded iron ores is not possible in today’s oxygenated oceans. Most banded iron formations are therefore Archean, having formed before Earth’s atmosphere (and oceans) became enriched in Oxygen. A few Neoproterozoic BIFs that formed after the “Great Oxygenation Event” are attributed to the prevalence of worldwide glaciations extending to the oceans and depriving their water from atmospheric Oxygen, hence allowing the dissolved Fe2+ concentration to increase in these oceans. According to this model, melting of glacial ice allowed for the re-oxygenation of the oceans and the precipitation of iron to form those Neoproterozoic banded iron formations.

Thirteen small BIFs occur in a 300,000 km2 large area in the central Eastern Desert of Egypt (CED). These BIFs are characterized by unusually high iron contents manifested by high iron to silicon ratios (Fe/Si) that also vary from one deposit to another. These formations occur interlayered with a variety of pyroclastic and igneous rocks that formed 750 – 800 million years ago (Ma), all of which were regionally metamorphosed. The igneous rocks are interpreted to represent fragments of the oceanic lithosphere, indicating that the entire sequence was emplaced onto the continental crust as a result of the closure of the ocean basin during the collisional stage of the Pan-African Orogeny ~ 640 Ma. Several igneous rocks of ages ranging from 670 to 500 Ma intrude the entire succession. Some scientists attribute the formation of the Egyptian BIFs to global glaciations, citing very few deposits that they interpreted as being of glacial origin, whereas others favor an origin related to strong volcanic activity. Most previous studies and hypotheses were limited to one or two of the thirteen deposits, and failed to establish a connection between these banded iron formations and the well–established tectonic history of the Eastern Desert of Egypt.

This project was carried out to understand the origin of the Egyptian BIFs in the context of the tectonic evolution of the Eastern Desert of Egypt and the Arabo-Nubian shield. Specific questions that we set out to answer included: To what extent is their origin related to glaciations or other global climatic events? Why are the deposits so high in Fe/Si? Why does Fe/Si vary from one deposit to another? When did these BIFs form? What is the role (if any) of post-depositional changes, regional metamorphism, or igneous activity in controlling the mineralogical and chemical composition of these banded iron formations.

Our research leads to the following conclusions

  • The Egyptian BIFs owe their origin to volcanic activity rather than glaciation. Rocks previously considered glaciogenic are characterized by volcanic textures.
  • Conditions of regional metamorphism in the CED ranged from 520 ± 30°C, 5 ± 2 kbar in the south to 400 ± 50°C, 3.5 ± 2 kbar in the north.
  • The occurrence of garnet in some BIFs in the southern part of CED is controlled by hydrothermal fluids emanating from nearby serpentinite bodies, and the higher temperatures of metamorphism (> 400°C).
  • The chemical similarity between all BIFs from the CED suggests their formation in the same basin under similar conditions. All deposits are characterized by marine signatures with some hydrothermal input.
